In this work, the impact of the host material composition on the temperature-dependent
luminescent properties of vanadium-doped nanocrystalline garnets was investigated. It was
demonstrated that the incorporation of Ga
modification of the emission color of the phosphor by the stabilization of the vanadium ions on the
oxidation state. Taking advantage from the fact that V
ions, due to their similar ionic radii,
mainly occupy the octahedral site of Ga
ions, the enlargement of their amount leads to the increase
of their emission intensity. Moreover, a growing number of V
ions cause a shortening of the
distance facilitating interionic energy transfer between them. Conducted studies
regarding the influence of temperature on the emission intensities of the vanadium ions at different
oxidation states reveal that the most susceptible to thermal quenching is the V

temperature. The higher the amount of Ga
ions in the host, the more evident the enhancement of
emission intensity and the lower the threshold temperature above which this enhancement
occurs. Taking advantage form the fact of opposite temperature dependence of V
intensities, their ratio was used to create the bandshape luminescent thermometer, to the best of our
knowledge, the highest relative sensitivity of V-based luminescent thermometers up to date S

concentration, the value of the relative sensitivity,
as well as the temperature at which
was observed, can be modified. Additionally, it was found

ions, the more evident the change of the chromatic

maximal sensitivity can be obtained. The dominant effect, which is responsible for described

In this work, the impact of the host material composition on the temperature-dependent
luminescent properties of vanadium-doped nanocrystalline garnets was investigated. It was
demonstrated that the incorporation of Ga
modiﬁcation of the emission color of the phosphor by the stabilization of the vanadium ions on
oxidation state. Taking advantage from the fact that V
ions, due to their similar ionic
radii, mainly occupy the octahedral site of Ga
ions, the enlargement of their amount leads to the
increase of their emission intensity. Moreover, a growing number of V
ions cause a shortening of the
distance facilitating interionic energy transfer between them. Conducted studies
regarding the inﬂuence of temperature on the emission intensities of the vanadium ions at di
